clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Bismuth Subsalicylate on Antimicrobial Use Among Adult Diarrhea Outpatients--Pakistan
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled Trial of the Impact of Bismuth Subsalicylate on Antimicrobial Use Among Adult Diarrhea Outpatients in Pakistan

lead_sponsor.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

clinical_study.source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to learn whether bismuth subsalicylate can reduce use of antibiotics among adults with diarrhea in Pakistan.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

secondary_outcome.description: Use of antidiarrheal medications, visits to other health professionals for diarrhea or complications of diarrhea, or expenditures on consultations and treatments for diarrheal illness

secondary_outcome.measure: Additional care obtained for diarrheal illness

Time to first formed stool Number of stools during first 48 h of observation Duration of abdominal pain Duration of nausea Time to resolution of illness (any of the following symptoms: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain) Severity of all symptoms of illness

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient experience with the study drug
secondary_outcome.description: i. Satisfaction with resolution of symptoms ii. Satisfaction with esthetics of study medication iii. Adverse effects

arm_group.description: Bismuth subsalicylate, 262 mg/chewable tablet, 2 tablets every hour as needed up to 16 tablets per 24 hours, for up to 48 hours.
Placebo chewable tablets, 2 every hour as needed up to 16 tablets per 24 h, for up to 48 h.

intervention.description: Chewable tablets identical to intervention tablets, but missing the bismuth subsalicylate

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Persons aged 15 - 65 years old
- Presenting with mild to moderate, non-bloody, acute diarrhea (â‰¥3 loose stools/day for <3 days) to participating health care settings
- For whom the study physicians recommend antimicrobial treatment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Is pregnant
- Requires hospitalization
- Has signs or symptoms of septicemia
- Has a primary complaint of another acute illness
- Has a serious chronic illness
- Has an allergy to aspirin
- Has been exposed to antimicrobial or antidiarrheal medications within 72 hours of enrollment
- Previously enrolled in study
